1. Building ConvNet from Scratch
  2. Use pre-trained ConvNet
  3. Use pre-trained ConvNet as fixed Feature Extractor
  4. Fine-tuning the Pre-trained ConvNet

[1]. Building ConvNet from Scratch

  1. Build your own ConvNet from scratch
  2. Use dataset to train the model
  3. Classify the object

(When to use: New dataset is large and very different from the original dataset)

[2]. Use pre-trained ConvNet

  1. Take pre-trained ConvNet(VGGNet, AlexNet, etc)
  2. Use similar kind of dataset to perform prediction as used by pre-trained ConvNet.
  3. Use ConvNet directly(without modifying any parameter used in model) to classify the object

[3]. Use pre-trained ConvNet as fixed Feature Extractor - Transfer Learning

  1. Take a ConvNet(like VGG16) pretrained on dataset(ike ImageNet)
  2. Remove the last fully-connected layer (this layerâ€™s outputs are the 1000 class scores for a different task like ImageNet)
  3. Then treat the rest of the ConvNet as a fixed feature extractor for the new dataset
  4. Use the extracted feature to train a linear classifier(e.g. Linear SVM or Softmax classifier) for the new dataset
  5. Classify the object

[4]. Fine-tuning the Pre-trained ConvNet - Transfer Learning

  1. Not only replace and retrain the classifier on top of the ConvNet on the new dataset, but to also fine-tune the weights of the pretrained network by continuing the backpropagation.
  2. Fine-tune all the layers of the ConvNet, or keep some of the earlier layers fixed (due to overfitting concerns) and only fine-tune some higher-level portion of the network.

(When to use: New dataset is large and similar to the original dataset)
